content.text: {"design_type":"other","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"primary school","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Drug take-up","Worm prevention behaviors"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Group 1 schools (early phase-in)","role":"experimental","description":"Schools assigned to Group 1; began receiving free deworming in 1998.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"Group 2 schools (mid phase-in)","role":"experimental","description":"Schools assigned to Group 2; began receiving free deworming in 1999.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1"]},{"arm_id":"A3","name":"Group 3 schools (late phase-in)","role":"experimental","description":"Schools assigned to Group 3; began receiving deworming drugs in 2001.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1"]},{"arm_id":"A4","name":"Cost-sharing schools (2001 re-randomization)","role":"treatment","description":"In 2001, half the (previously treated) schools were randomized to cost-sharing for deworming drugs.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A5","name":"Free treatment schools (2001 re-randomization)","role":"unknown","description":"In 2001, half the (previously treated) schools continued to receive free treatment (comparison condition for cost-sharing).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A6","name":"Verbal commitment offered","role":"treatment","description":"Randomly selected subsample of pupils asked about intention to come to school on treatment day and whether workers should bring pills for them.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3"]},{"arm_id":"A7","name":"No verbal commitment offer","role":"unknown","description":"Pupils not offered the verbal commitment questions; both groups received the same information about deworming and treatment date.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["75 primary schools were randomly divided into three groups (1/2/3) of 25 schools each, using stratification by geographical area (division then zone) and systematic assignment (every third school) after sorting zones alphabetically and schools by enrollment size.","Program phase-in timing was tied to these groups: Group 1 started 1998, Group 2 started 1999, Group 3 started 2001; treatment/control status varies by year (e.g., 1998: Group 1 treated, Groups 2-3 control; 1999-2000: Groups 1-2 treated, Group 3 control).","In 2001, schools (described as Groups 1 and 2 / the 50 previously free-treatment schools) were randomized again: half to cost-sharing and half to continued free treatment.","Verbal commitment was assigned at the individual (pupil) level as a random subsample of pupils."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The 75 program schools were randomly divided into three groups (Groups 1, 2, and 3) of 25 schools each... Due to the NGO’s administrative and financial constraints, the schools were phased into the program over the course of 1998-2001... Group 1 schools began receiving free deworming in 1998, Group 2 schools in 1999, while Group 3 schools began receiving the drugs in 2001. The project design implies that in 1998, Group 1 schools were treatment schools while Group 2 and 3 schools were the control, and in 1999 and 2000, Group 1 and 2 schools were the treatment schools and Group 3 schools the control... In 2002 all schools received free treatment.","supports":"Cluster random assignment of schools into three phase-in groups and the implied time-varying treatment/control status."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Cost-sharing: Between 1998 and 1999 PSDP delivered free deworming pills to 50 sample schools in Groups 1 and 2. In 2001, they were randomized again to assign half the schools to a cost-sharing intervention while the other half continued to receive free treatment.","supports":"Second-stage school-level randomization in 2001: cost-sharing vs continued free treatment."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Verbal commitment: A random subsample of pupils were asked whether they were planning to come to school on the next treatment day and whether the PSDP workers should bring pills for them on that day... All pupils interviewed—including both those offered the opportunity for verbal commitment and those not offered this opportunity—were provided the same information on the effects of deworming and the upcoming date of medical treatment.","supports":"Individual-level randomization for verbal commitment (subsample) and comparison group definition."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"PRIMARY_OUTCOMES_RAW: 1. Drug take-up (measures effect of social links, cost-sharing, and verbal commitment), 2. Worm prevention behaviors (measures effect of health education)","supports":"Primary outcomes."}],"notes":"Design involves cluster randomization of schools into phase-in groups plus a subsequent school-level re-randomization (cost-sharing) and an individual-level randomization (verbal commitment). Labeled as 'other' (multi-stage/mixed-level) rather than simple multiarm or factorial. 'Health education' is described as delivered to all treatment schools, but no separate randomization to health education vs none is stated; 'social links' are measurement/exposure rather than a randomized intervention in the provided text. The mapping of which exact schools/pupils are included in each randomization (and whether cost-sharing re-randomization applied to all 75 or only Groups 1-2) is not fully explicit, so completeness is 'partial'."}

{"design_type":"other","unit_of_randomization_canonical":null,"is_clustered":false,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Whether an employer calls or emails in response to a submitted resume."],"arms":[],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":[],"design_completeness":"unclear","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"\"We construct fictitious resumes, randomly vary the institution from which the job applicant received a degree or certificate, and apply to job vacancies that are posted on a large, national job search website.\"","supports":"Indicates there is random variation in credential institution on resumes; suggests an audit study with randomized resume characteristics but does not specify assignment unit or exact treatment cells."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"\"While our primary research question concerns employers’ valuations of a for-profit versus public credential, we also test the impact of having any credential for job vacancies that do not require it.\"","supports":"Mentions at least two conceptual comparisons (for-profit vs public; any credential vs none) but does not enumerate arms/cells or assignment mechanism."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"\"EXPERIMENTAL_DESIGN: See the paper and pre-analysis plan for details.\"","supports":"Registry entry does not provide the experimental design details needed to enumerate arms/factors or assignment rules."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"\"PRIMARY_OUTCOMES_RAW: Whether an employer calls or emails in response to a submitted resume.\"","supports":"Defines the primary outcome."}],"notes":"Registry text indicates a resume audit field experiment with randomized institution/credential attributes, but provides insufficient detail to (i) specify the unit of randomization (resume, vacancy, employer) or (ii) enumerate treatment arms/factor levels. Marked as design_type 'other' and completeness 'unclear' pending paper/pre-analysis plan."}

{"design_type":"simple_multiarm","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"cluster (unspecified)","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Decision to participate in DrumNet","Growing of an export crop","Income","Participation in the formal financial sector","Profitability of DrumNet"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Treatment-Credit","role":"treatment","description":"DrumNet package including a four-week orientation course, personal savings account, group-of-five joint liability structure, and access to an in-kind loan/line of credit (with contribution to an insurance fund as partial collateral), plus price negotiation and produce pickup at harvest; proceeds credited to savings account net of loan repayment.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"Treatment-NoCredit","role":"treatment","description":"DrumNet package without the opportunity for credit; includes the four-week orientation course, opening a personal savings account, and marketing services at harvest (price negotiation and produce pickup; proceeds credited to savings account).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq3","eq4"]},{"arm_id":"A3","name":"Control group","role":"control","description":"Control group (no further details provided in registry text).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq5"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["Clustered randomized control trial (clusters used for randomization, but cluster type not specified in registry text).","Three-arm design: Treatment with credit, Treatment without credit, and a control group."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"All individuals in the treatment groups received a four-week orientation course... In addition, all treatment individuals opened a personal savings account with a local commercial bank","supports":"Common components for both treatment arms (orientation + savings account)."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Individuals in the \"Treatment-Credit\" group also contributed... After being organized into groups of five, which were jointly liable for individual loans taken out, individuals in the Treatment-Credit group received an in-kind loan...","supports":"Treatment-Credit arm includes credit/loan features and group-of-five joint liability."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Individuals in a \"Treatment-NoCredit\" group received the same DrumNet package, only without the opportunity for credit.","supports":"Treatment-NoCredit arm definition (package without credit)."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"At harvest time, for individuals in both treatment groups, DrumNet negotiated prices with an exporter and arranged a produce pickup... credited the remainder to the individual savings accounts","supports":"Marketing/price negotiation/pickup and payment flow for both treatment arms."},{"id":"eq5","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Thus, the experimental design includes two treatments, one with credit and one without, and a control group.","supports":"Three arms including a control group; two treatments (with credit vs without)."},{"id":"eq6","source_doc":"registry","quote":"We conduct a clustered randomized control trial with DrumNet","supports":"Randomization is clustered (cluster RCT) though cluster type is not specified."}],"notes":"Design is a cluster RCT per registry text, but the registry excerpt does not specify what the clusters are (e.g., village, farmer group, location) nor the analysis unit. Heterogeneity by prior export-crop experience is mentioned but is not an experimental factor."}

{"design_type":"simple_multiarm","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"village council","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Share of female pradhans or concilor seat contestants","Share of female pradhans or councilors winning unreserved elections","Voter bias towards females"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Never reserved for a female","role":"experimental","description":"Villages/councils where the position was never reserved for a female leader across the two election cycles (1998, 2003).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"Reserved once in 1998","role":"experimental","description":"Villages/councils where the position was reserved for a female leader in 1998 only.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A3","name":"Reserved once in 2003","role":"experimental","description":"Villages/councils where the position was reserved for a female leader in 2003 only.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A4","name":"Reserved in both 1998 and 2003","role":"experimental","description":"Villages/councils where the position was reserved for a female leader in both 1998 and 2003.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["Random reservation policy: one-third of councilor positions in each council and one-third of pradhan positions across councils were required to be reserved for women.","Treatment status defined by randomized mandated exposure history over two elections (1998 and 2003): never reserved; reserved in 1998 only; reserved in 2003 only; reserved in both years."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The government randomly required one-third of councilor positions in each council, and one-third of pradhan positions across councils, to be reserved for women.","supports":"Unit of randomization is at the council/village council level and assignment is randomized via reservation requirements."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Thus, villages could be organized into one of four \"treatment\" groups: the position was never reserved for a female; reserved once in 1998; reserved once in 2003; or reserved in both 1998 and 2003.","supports":"Defines the four experimental arms based on reservation exposure across 1998 and 2003 elections."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"In this paper we exploit random variation in mandated exposure to female leaders across village councils in India.","supports":"Confirms randomized variation across village councils (clustered assignment)."}],"notes":"Design treated as a 4-arm multiarm RCT at the village council level based on randomized reservation exposure across two election cycles. Marked partial because the registry text does not clarify whether these four groups apply separately to pradhan reservations vs councilor-seat reservations, nor whether analysis is at village, council, or individual-voter level."}

{
  "design_type": "simple_multiarm",
  "unit_of_randomization_canonical": "school",
  "is_clustered": true,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "Access to schooling (enrollment rates)",
    "Student learning outcomes",
    "Teacher behavior (absenteeism, time on task, corporal punishment, job satisfaction, turnover)",
    "School management (monitoring visits, teacher support/training, infrastructure/materials, extracurricular activities)",
    "Parental engagement in education (education expenditure, involvement in school activities)",
    "Equity (socio-economic composition of students accessing PSL schools)",
    "Equity (spillover effects on nearby non-PSL schools)"
  ],
  "arms": [
    {
      "arm_id": "A1",
      "name": "PSL treatment (school assigned to be managed by a private operator)",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "PSL-eligible schools randomly selected for treatment; treated schools administered by one of eight private operators.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq2",
        "eq3"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "A2",
      "name": "Control (PSL-eligible school not selected for treatment)",
      "role": "control",
      "description": "Within each operator-specific eligibility group, half of schools were treated and the rest served as controls.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq3"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "From 185 PSL-eligible schools, 92 schools across 12 counties were randomly selected for treatment.",
    "The 185 schools were partitioned into 8 mutually exclusive operator-specific groups based on operator criteria; each group contained twice the number of schools the operator would manage.",
    "Within each operator-specific group, half of schools were randomly chosen to be treated and the rest served as controls.",
    "Each treated school was assigned to (administered by) one of the eight private operators (consistent with the operator-specific grouping).",
    "Students are sampled from 2015/2016 enrollment logs (pre-awareness) and analyzed as belonging to their original school regardless of subsequent attendance (ITT framework)."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "partial",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Based on criteria established by the evaluation team, MoE, and operators, 185 PSL-eligible schools were identified.",
      "supports": "Sampling frame of PSL-eligible schools (185 schools)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "92 schools across 12 counties were randomly selected for treatment. Each treated school will be administered by one of the eight private operators.",
      "supports": "Number of treated schools; school-level assignment to treatment and operator administration for treated schools."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Based on these criteria, the universe of 185 experimental schools was split into 8 mutually exclusive groups corresponding to the 8 operators, with each operator’s group containing twice the number of schools that operator will manage. Within each of these groups, half of the schools were randomly chosen to be treated, with the rest serving as controls.",
      "supports": "Stratified/blocked randomization within operator-specific groups; existence of control group; unit is schools."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq4",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Since the composition of students may change across PSL and control schools in response to treatment assignment, we will sample students from 2015/2016 enrollment logs... Each student will be evaluated as part of her/his “original” school, regardless of what school (if any) s/he attended in subsequent years. Using this panel dataset, we can recover the effect of PSL schools under an Intention-to-Treat (ITT) framework.",
      "supports": "Student sampling/measurement rule and ITT analysis approach tied to original school assignment."
    }
  ],
  "notes": "Although treated schools are administered by one of eight operators, the registry text does not explicitly define separate experimental arms by operator (i.e., operator-specific treatment cells). Randomization is school-level with blocking by operator-specific eligibility groups; treated vs control is clear, but operator-level arm structure is not fully specified, so design completeness is marked partial."
}

{"design_type":"factorial","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"household","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Access: share of all illness episodes treated with an ACT","Targeting: share of ACT takers who are actually malaria positive","Under-treatment (UT): share of true malaria illnesses not treated with ACTs (estimated indirectly)","Over-treatment (OT): share of non-malaria illnesses treated with ACTs (estimated indirectly)"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Full price ACT voucher","role":"treatment","description":"Households receive vouchers to purchase ACTs at full price from nearest drug store.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"ACT subsidy voucher (any level)","role":"treatment","description":"Households receive ACT vouchers subsidized at one of three subsidy levels: 92%, 88%, or 80%.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A2a","name":"ACT subsidy voucher (92%)","role":"experimental","description":"ACT voucher subsidy level 92%.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A2b","name":"ACT subsidy voucher (88%)","role":"experimental","description":"ACT voucher subsidy level 88%.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A2c","name":"ACT subsidy voucher (80%)","role":"experimental","description":"ACT voucher subsidy level 80%.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]},{"arm_id":"A3","name":"ACT subsidy + subsidized RDT","role":"treatment","description":"Households receive subsidized rapid diagnostic malaria tests (RDT) in addition to ACT subsidies.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3"]},{"arm_id":"A4","name":"Surprise free RDT offer (random subset)","role":"experimental","description":"Random subset of households in all treatment groups are offered a free RDT after completing their transaction at the drug shop (or at home if patient did not come).","evidence_quote_ids":["eq4","eq5"]}],"factors":[{"factor_id":"F1","name":"ACT price/subsidy voucher","levels":[{"level_id":"F1L1","name":"Full price","description":"Voucher to purchase ACTs at full price.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq6"]},{"level_id":"F1L2","name":"Subsidized ACT (level varies)","description":"ACTs subsidized at 92%, 88% or 80%.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq2"]}]},{"factor_id":"F2","name":"RDT subsidy bundled with ACT subsidy","levels":[{"level_id":"F2L0","name":"No subsidized RDT bundled","description":"Households receive ACT-related voucher only (full price or subsidized), with no mention of subsidized RDT bundled in the core arm.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq1","eq2"]},{"level_id":"F2L1","name":"Subsidized RDT bundled","description":"Households receive subsidized RDTs in addition to ACT subsidies.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq3","eq6"]}]},{"factor_id":"F3","name":"Post-purchase 'surprise' free RDT measurement offer","levels":[{"level_id":"F3L0","name":"No surprise free RDT offer","description":"Household not selected into the random subset for the surprise free RDT offer.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq4"]},{"level_id":"F3L1","name":"Surprise free RDT offer","description":"Household selected into a random subset (across all groups) to receive an offer of a free RDT after voucher redemption; administered at shop or at home if needed.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq4","eq5"]}]}],"assignment_rules":["Households were assigned to one of three treatment statuses: full price ACT, ACT subsidy, or ACT+RDT subsidy.","Within all treatment groups, a random subset of households was selected to receive the offer of a 'surprise' free RDT after the drug shop transaction.","Sampling frame: households within a 4 km radius catchment area of each of four rural drug stores were sampled at baseline; at end of survey households were informed of treatment status and given vouchers accordingly."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Sample households are assigned to one of three treatment arms. In the first treatment arm, households received vouchers to purchase ACTs at full price from their nearest drug store.","supports":"Existence and description of Arm 1 (full price ACT voucher) and assignment to three arms."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"In the second treatment arm, the ACTs are subsidized at 92%, 88% or 80%.","supports":"Existence and description of Arm 2 and the three subsidy levels (92/88/80)."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"In the third treatment arm, households received subsidized rapid diagnostic malaria tests (RDT) in addition to the ACT subsidies.","supports":"Existence and description of Arm 3 (ACT subsidy + subsidized RDT)."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"the researchers also selected a random subset of the households in all treatment groups to receive the offer of a “surprise” free RDT after they completed their transaction at the drug shop.","supports":"Cross-cutting randomization: surprise free RDT offer to a random subset across all treatment groups."},{"id":"eq5","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Additionally, to test what proportion of patients buying ACT was actually positive for malaria, a random subsample was given the option of a free RDT test after they had redeemed their ACT voucher. If the patient had not come to the drug store, the officer went to the patient’s home to administer the test.","supports":"Operational details of surprise free RDT offer and that it is a random subsample."},{"id":"eq6","source_doc":"registry","quote":"At the end of the survey, the household was informed of its treatment status (full price ACT, ACT subsidy or ACT+RDT subsidy) and a voucher given accordingly. Each household was given two vouchers for ACT and two for RDT (if applicable) that could be redeemed at the study drug store.","supports":"Unit appears to be household; treatment statuses named; voucher distribution including RDT when applicable."},{"id":"eq7","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The ultimate aim in this trial is to study how retail sector ACT subsidies impact both under-treatment (UT , the share of true malaria illnesses that are not treated with ACTs) and over-treatment ( OT , the share of non-malaria illnesses that are treated with ACTs). Since collecting the data to directly measure these outcomes was not logistically feasible, UT and OT are estimated indirectly by measuring:, 1) Access: the share of all illness episodes treated with an ACT, 2) Targeting: the share of ACT takers who are actually malaria positive","supports":"Primary outcomes: UT and OT (indirectly estimated), and measured components Access and Targeting."}],"notes":"Unit of randomization is taken to be the household because the registry text repeatedly describes assignment and voucher distribution at the household level. Marked as clustered (non-individual) under the extraction rule, though households are not clusters in the usual sense; interpret as household-level randomization. Design marked partial because (i) it is unclear whether the 92/88/80 subsidy levels are separately randomized within Arm 2 and/or also apply within Arm 3 (ACT+RDT), and (ii) the registry does not enumerate the full set of factorial treatment cells implied by combining subsidy level with RDT bundling."}

{"design_type":"cluster_rct","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"natural spring","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Spring water quality","Home (household) water quality","Child health and nutrition impacts","Behavior changes towards transport, storage and treatment of water"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"A1","name":"Treatment springs (round 1 & 2 completed)","role":"treatment","description":"Springs completed in round 1 and round 2 of protection construction were considered treatment springs.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq4"]},{"arm_id":"A2","name":"Comparison springs (not completed in round 1 & 2)","role":"unknown","description":"All other sampled springs (not completed in round 1 & 2) were considered comparison springs.","evidence_quote_ids":["eq4"]}],"factors":[],"assignment_rules":["From the remaining suitable springs, 200 springs were randomly selected using a computer random number generator to receive protection.","Treatment status was defined by implementation timing: springs completed in round 1 and round 2 were treatment; the rest were comparison.","Households were sampled within springs by first listing spring users via nominations; households named by two different respondents were designated spring users; 7–8 households were randomly selected per spring user list."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Springs for this study were selected from the universe of 535 unprotected springs in Busia and Butere districts. Technical staff visited each site to determine which springs were suitable for protection. Springs known to be seasonally dry were eliminated, as were sites with upstream contaminants (e.g., latrines, graves).","supports":"Sampling frame and eligibility screening for springs."},{"id":"eq2","source_doc":"registry","quote":"From the remaining suitable springs, 200 were randomly selected (using a computer random number generator) to receive protection.","supports":"Random selection/assignment mechanism and unit (springs) for receiving protection."},{"id":"eq3","source_doc":"registry","quote":"The water quality improvement construction was done by partner NGO, International Child Support, over a period of four years.","supports":"Implementation context and phased rollout over time."},{"id":"eq4","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Springs completed in round 1 and round 2 were considered treatment springs and the rest comparison. This resulted in 91 treatment and 93 comparison springs in the final sample.","supports":"Definition of treatment vs comparison groups and final numbers by arm."},{"id":"eq5","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Users at each spring were asked to name others who also used the spring. When a household was named by two different respondents, it was designated as a “spring user”. Seven to eight households were randomly selected from the “spring user” list of each spring to be included in the sample. The baseline sample size was 1500 households.","supports":"Household sampling within spring clusters and baseline sample size."},{"id":"eq6","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Data on spring water quality, household water quality and household health were collected 3-4 months after round 1 of spring protection, 1 year after round 2 of spring protection and five months after the second survey.","supports":"Outcome measurement schedule and types of data collected."},{"id":"eq7","source_doc":"registry","quote":"PRIMARY_OUTCOMES_RAW: Spring water quality, home water quality, child health and nutrition impacts, behavior changes towards transport, storage and treatment of water","supports":"Primary outcomes listed in the registry entry."}],"notes":"Design is treated as a cluster RCT because the intervention is assigned at the spring level and households are sampled within springs. Completeness is marked partial because the text states springs were randomly selected to receive protection, but also defines treatment vs comparison based on completion in rounds 1–2 vs later; it is unclear whether this induces non-random treatment classification in the final analysis sample or reflects randomized phased implementation."}

{"design_type":"factorial","unit_of_randomization_canonical":"kebele (subdistrict)","is_clustered":true,"analysis_unit_canonical":null,"primary_outcomes_dedup":["Child stunting (height-for-age Z-scores (HAZ)<-2) for children under 24 months","Minimally acceptable diet for children under 24 months","Food security (household food gap in months)","Depression severity score (PHQ-9)","Gender norms and female empowerment (multiple measures)","Assets (Total Index, Productive, Livestock)","Access to savings","Access to credit (total value of productive/consumption loan)","Income from livestock and poultry","Aspirations (education aspirations/attainment measures)"],"arms":[{"arm_id":"arm1","name":"Treatment 1: L* + N*","role":"treatment","description":"Enhanced livelihoods package provided to the poorest 10 out of 18 sample households in those kebeles."],"design_completeness":"partial","extraction_sources":["registry"],"evidence_quotes":[{"id":"eq1","source_doc":"registry","quote":"Intervention L: SPIR livelihood activities: starting
